awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: RUI: Collaborative Research: Data-Driven Methods in Classical Knot Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The philosophy driving this mathematics research project is to approach the study of knots from a data-driven perspective.  The project aims to employ powerful computational techniques to calculate invariants on a large scale, make these algorithms and their output available to the community, and use computational resources to empirically arrive at and test conjectures. The investigators plan to develop new algorithms that will expand existing databases of knot invariants and may lead to resolving old open problems, thus also broadening the potential for applications throughout the sciences, from molecular biology to quantum physics. Mathematical tools for studying knots generally fall into two categories: geometric and algebraic.  The project will rely on large-scale computations to analyze connections between these two points of view, harnessing the data collected to attack questions that have so far remained intractable.  In addition, the project intends to make deep questions in the field accessible to students by developing new combinatorial and exploratory techniques.  The investigators will actively engage students in impactful research, directly addressing known pipeline gaps in the field of mathematics.

The research goals of this project include: (1) approaching the meridional rank conjecture from a computational perspective, with the aim of verifying the conjecture for all tabulated knots and extracting theoretical results from these empirical findings; (2) designing an efficient algorithm to compute bridge numbers for large classes of knots by combining techniques for finding lower and upper bounds for these numbers from knot diagrams;  (3) computing homotopy ribbon obstructions for slice knots using Kjuchukova's invariants and developing algorithms to test potential counterexamples to the slice-ribbon conjecture; (4) constructing four-manifolds as branched covers of the sphere with knots as singularities on the branching sets; classifying these branched covers and studying, with the help of trisections, the smooth structures on the four-manifolds constructed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop new computational tools to attack major open problems in knot theory and low-dimensional topology. A physical model of a knot can be constructed by taking a piece of string, tangling it up, and then gluing the two ends of the string together.  Knots have broad applications throughout the sciences, from DNA topology to quantum physics.   Knot theorists primarily study knots using invariants, which are tools for telling knots apart.  Another way to study knots is to study the possible surfaces they bound--imagine a soap film, whose edge is a given knotted loop of string.  In dimension 3, only an unknotted loop can bound a disk with no self-intersections; however, if we allow the surface to pass into dimension 4, other knots can bound disks as well. These knots are called slice.

A famous unsolved problem in low-dimensional topology, the Slice-Ribbon Problem, asks whether every slice knot bounds a ribbon disk, which is a disk in 3-dimensional space that intersects itself in a particularly simple way. We proved that a knot invariant defined by Kjuchukova takes on values in a particular range when the knot bounds a ribbon disk, and more generally a ribbon surface, meaning this invariant can be used to test potential counterexamples to the Slice-Ribbon Problem and its higher-genus generalizations.

This project then developed new algorithms for computing these ribbon obstructions, allowing one to compute the invariant for complicated knots with many crossings. Our techniques used a construction called branched covers. Roughly speaking, a space Y is an n-fold branched cover of X if Y can be "folded up" n times to create X. The branching set, a knot, is the "crease" of the fold.  Branched covers are a rich source of knot invariants, and our methods led to new algorithms for computing other knot invariants as well.  Our techniques also leveraged trisections, a new method for representing building 4-dimensional spaces; another biproduct of our work above is the development of techniques for building trisected manifolds as irregular branched covers over knotted surfaces.

Because of its computational nature, this project provided concrete training for dozens of undergraduate and postbaccalaureate students at Smith College.  As part of the broader impacts of the project, the PI continued to co-direct the Center for Women in Mathematics at Smith College, which includes the postbaccalaureate program, as well as an annual conference for undergraduate students. Both programs support students at critical transition points, encouraging them to continue to study mathematics at the graduate level.  This was particularly crucial in the wake of the pandemic--students whose coursework was disrupted were able to return to mathematics, take advanced coursework, gain research experience, and enter PhD programs in the mathematical sciences.
